DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: If Don and Lee Williams of Edgewater, Fla., are wondering what happened to the check they mailed with their water bill last month, it just arrived _ in New York City. The $33.87 check sent to ``City, Box 100,'' was rerouted by the post office in Jacksonville, Fla., to the Big Apple, where it showed up at the Department of Investigation, said department Commissioner Kevin Frawley. ``This is the kind of thing, if you live in New York, that convinces you this is `The City' in this country,'' said Frawley. Box 100 is an address set up by New York City officials for residents to send complaints, tips on wrongdoing or just about anything else, Frawley said. The same address in Edgewater, apparently is where you pay your water bill. Frawley said he had not yet contacted the Williams couple to find out if they have had any trouble with their water service.

If President Bush doesn't eat the 75-pound health-food tamale sent by a tortilla factory, he can donate it to a homeless shelter, but he ought to try some of the smaller tamales included in the box, said the tamale maker. Taylor Ford of La Suprema Tortilleria restaurant and tortilla factory said Thursday he hoped the 5-by-3-foot, 22-inch thick chicken tamale would ``promote good eating. You know, the president is going to need his energy during this Panama crisis.'' Ford's wife, La Suprema manager Lucy Cruz, said the tamale is a ``Texas-size holiday greeting to the president and his family. President and Mrs. Bush can eat healthy but still enjoy holiday feasting.'' Unlike other tamales _ a native Mexican food of minced meat, peppers and seasonings rolled in cornmeal and wrapped in corn shucks _ the one steamed for El Presidente contains no preservatives, lard, salt or sugar, Ford said. It contains 50 pounds of organic blue corn meal and 25 pounds of chicken smothered in pureed red chile. ``Red, white and blue _ isn't that appropriate?'' Ford said.

Richard Beckner won't slide down your chimney, but for a small fee he will bring packages to your door dressed as Old St. Nick. ``I'll take my time, do a little ho-ho with them and ask the kids what they want for Christmas,'' said Beckner, one of a handful of Postal Service employees who will deliver packages over the weekend dressed as Santa Claus. ``You just don't put the box down and say goodbye.'' The Santa service costs $12. ``We just decided to do something for the community,'' said Joe Stultz, superintendent of window services for the Huntington Post Office. ``We're losing money on it.''
